It was my impression that menuki assigned to Ezo were not only made with a =
thin plate but also they had a unique method of -- and I'm not sure of the =
correct terminology here -- gilding on them, something similar to found in =
Chinese artworks. A year or so ago I wrote an article for the JSS/US to ill=
ustrate some menuki depicting the mythical "baku." The one set of menuki we=
re fairly large sized as one might expect in Ezo but the other set were wha=
t I'd call "normal" menuki size, but they also had all the other characteri=
stics of Ezo. To me, it seemed somewhat unusual to find the "baku" creature=
 depicted on menuki thought to be Ezo. Earlier, I did show these to both Ji=
m Gilbert and Bob Haynes and they agreed that they appeared to be Ezo works=
. But really, I wonder who knows; Buttweiler's writings on Ezo are about al=
l I've ever really found regarding Ezo, at least what comes to mind tonight=
. 

Here now is a nice Echizen Kanenori katana that was found in nice quali=
ty WWII gunto mounting. What's kind of unique is that the tsuka has menuki =
depicting a fairly large "tiger" which -- judging while held in place under=
 wrapping -- really does have the look of possibly being Ezo. The "worn gol=
d gilding" is there, the size is right, but I wonder. I'd love to remove th=
ese but find it difficult to bring myself to unwrap this tsuka in order to =
"get them into my hand." (The wrap is already broken, but remains almost al=
l there and intact.) Now I would think it unusual, as with the "baku," to f=
ind Ezo menuki depicting a running "tiger." It is a temptation to have a lo=
ok at these, for sure! If these are no Ezo, I wonder where they should be p=
laced? 

Ron
STL

  I don't think there is any real con=
nection between Ezo and Ko-Mino menuki, Ezo menuki are generally larger and=
 with a less detailed design (large cherry blossom etc), I wonder if those =
smaller Ezo menuki with a detailed design are Ezo at all.

  Alan

y 
  understanding of early menuki from Buttweiler the Ezo (aka: Shoki 
  K=
inko) developed into the Ko Mino but I am wondering if the Ezo 
  continued=
 along side the Mino group. These are very sophisticated in 
  construction=
 but have the typical patina of the Ezo although in much 
  better conditio=
n than usually seen.
  Thanks much!
